html:
MicroBiome Simulator is a cellular automaton based off of the Game of Life by John Horton Conway.


In this simulation, the grid on the left 'evolves' over time, depending on the status of it's cells.
Each cell is either Alive or Dead. The dark cells are alive, and you can't see the Dead cells. Whether or not a cell is alive depends on how many of it's neighbours are alive.

If a cell is alive and has 2 or 3 alive neighbours, it remains alive. If a cell is dead but has 3 alive neighbours, it comes to life.


The numbers in the cells on the left represent how many neighbours it has alive. Notice the neighbour counts; the center never changes because it always has 3 neighbours, but the outside squares switch because the dead cells have 3.
This is another common pattern that emerges. This square stays the same, as the alive cells always have 3 alive neighbours and the dead cells never have more than 2.

Simple enough, right?


Patterns can get a little bit more complicated though, and there are different types of patterns. This type is called an oscillator, as the pattern keeps repeating.
And, this type is a Space Ship because it moves across the grid.

And a type called Agar... I think you get the picture.


To see more patterns, you can Add Patterns here.


If you want to learn more, check out the wiki.


If you want to know how it was made, check out the Developer Notes.
